pullrequest.title: Refactoring the cmake scripts to use ignition-cmake

content.raw:
Hypothetically, it could have a slight benefit to compile time, but I doubt it would be perceptible to a human.

There's a big drawback, though: There could be other files from other libraries with the name `Filename.hh`. In principle, using `#include "Filename.hh"` should ensure that the compiler chooses to use our local version of `Filename.hh`, but all it takes is one little slip-up for someone to accidentally write `#include <Filename.hh>`, and then we're at risk of the compiler choosing the wrong version of the file. So I would strongly protest using that scheme for installed headers. We should, however, do exactly that for source files inside the `src/` directory when they are including non-installed headers that live inside of the `src/` directory.

If we want to use quotes for stylistic reasons, we can do that. It wouldn't be doing any favors for the compiler, but it also wouldn't do any noticeable harm, as long as we keep the `ignition/common/`.
